BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1915.

NOBLE'S TRIPLE BREAKS UP GAME

UNDERCLASS TEAMS ORGANIZE

LAFAYETTE WINS DUAL MEET

Sutton Scores Him in Eleventh Inning
With Sacrifice Fly and Then Treats
Crowd to Pretzels.

Freshmen and Sophomores Make Preparations for Interclass Lacrosse and
Baseball Games—Close Contests Expected.

Black and Blue Puts Up Good Fight in
Close Contest, 47-57 Tappan
Stars Again.

The 'Varsity nine required eleven
innings to get the better of the
Delaware College baseball team in
the annual game at Newark, Del.,
Saturday aftenoon. The score was
7 to 6.
Jack Defandorf, who was on the
mound for Hopkins, pitched a
splendid game with the exception of
the two innings—the third and the
ninth—in which four runs were
scored. Hoch, Delaware's pitcher,
struck out ten men, and from the
third to the ninth inning allowed no
hits, but Hopkins' heavy hitting
lead-off men found him in the ninth
and eleventh periods for enough
hits to break the even score.
Bill Noble, desperate and hungry
(for it was nearly six o'clock), told
his teammates on the bench just before he went to bat in the eleventh
inning that he was due for a long
hit. He poled out a beautiful triple
to center, and scored on Sutton's
sacrifice fly, thus winning the fourth
consecutive game for the Black and
Blue.
The battle was certainly thrilling.
Hopkins got 'a lead of three runs
over Delaware in the third inning,
but the Blue and Gray evened the
score in the fifth. Then came the
struggle to break the deadlock. Hopkins scored twice in the ninth, but
Delaware evened un in its portion
of the inning. The tenth period
lasted fifteen minutes.
Capt. Pete Porter, the first to bat
for Hopkins, sent a liner to first
base, but Geoghegan fielded it in
big-league style. Then Bill Noble
drove out his triple. Inasmuch as it
was a question of getting only one
run to win, Butts Sutton concluded
that it would do to send out a fly
long enough to allow Noble to
score. This he did. Delaware went
out in one-two-three order in its
end of the inning.
One of the results of the game
was the establishment of the fact
that Coach Eddie Hooper hasn't
heart failure. "After this game,"
he said, "no doctor can ever tell me
I have heart failure. If I had it
I would have been dead before the
ninth inning."
When the game was over the
players had just enough time to
dress to catch the 6.13 train for
Baltimore. A number wanted to
"make" the cotillon and it was decided to forego the dinner which
Delaware had prepared. Butts
Sutton, dressing earlier than the
rest, found Newark's general store
and laid in a generous supply of
oranges, fruit crackers and pretzels,
(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

The Freshman-Sophomore class
teams will probably be stronger this
season and will be more evenly
matched than they have been in several years. The lacrosse teams, especially, will be well fortified with
men from the 'Varsity squad; and
consequently the annual class game
is expected to be hotly contested.
The sophomores have Stuart,
Baker and Brooks, the three 'Varsity
close-defense men, as a nucleus for
their defense; and Boyce, Wilson
and Paul Sutton on the attack.
With these men as a basis, the
second-year men are confident of
putting a fast team on the field, and
of atoning for the defeat in football
which they sulfered last fall.
The freshmen are equally hopeful
of having a winning team. Their
attack contains Wolfe, Woodward,
Frank Sutton, Mealy and Swartz—
all on the 'Varsity squad—and several other candidates, including
Evans, Hooper, Rothschild and Miller. The freshmen defense is not
as strong as that of the sophomores.
Chalmers has been showing up well
at goal. Hoffman, Gillet, P. Nelson, Love and Cromwell will probably be the other defense men.
Allen K. Chalmers, manager of
the freshmen baseball team, reports
that the prospects for a good showing are exceedingly bright. There
are a large number of candidates
out for the team, two or three men
contesting for every position. The
list of available pitchers is especially
long. There is Hollingsworth, the
'Varsity pitcher, who will probably
hurl for the freshmen, and there are
Love, Tavjor, Rolker and Witz, all
on the 'Varsity squad.
A game with the Towson High
School nine has already been arranged for the freshmen team, and
it is planned to play several other
local prenaratory schools before the
game with the sophomores.
We consider health and the right
attitude toward health as fundamental. Health is not possible
without "good times." Health of
the. body is of little value without
health of the soul, and we encourage thoughtfulness and earnestness.
Good health; clear thinking and
right attitude are ideals toward
which we are ever striving.
It requires some grit and a sense
of honor to turn one's back squarely
on his weaknesses and keep it there.

The last three events decided the
dual meet with Lafayette, held at
Homewood last Saturday, against
the Black and Blue after a close and
exciting contest. .Hopkins was in
the lead (luring the first part of the
Meet, and the tenth event found the
score tied. Then the visitors took
the lead by winning both places in
the half mile, and later ended the
contest on the best side of 57 to 47.
Tappan once more starred for
Hopkins,. being the highest individual point-winner of the meet
with seventeen and one-half points.
He won the high hurdles and the
pole vault, took second place in the
low hurdles and the broad jump.
and tied with Captain Connolly of
the Hopkins team for second place
in the high jump. His performance
in the high hurdles was exceptionally good. Straus also distinguished
himself. by his good work in the
sprints. He won the 220-yard dash
in very good time (22V-, seconds)
and was second in the Too-yard
dash. Wright, who on account of
an injured muscle had not appeared
for Hopkins before this meet, won
the Too-yard dash in beautiful
form, but in the 220 his leg went
back on him again and he was forced
to make a weak fiMsh, only taking
third place.
Kleinstehn, of Lafayette, ran a
beautiful race in the mile run and
finished in 4 minutes, 4434 seconds.
Tiall trailed him closely all the way,
but was unable to make up the
three-yard lead on the home stretch.
Maxfield, Lafayette's weight man,
made exceptionally good throws in
both the discus and shot put, making 114 feet and 43 feet. respectively, in these events. Connolly was a
good second to both performances.
The Red and White runners ran
a "heady" race in the quarter mile,
and succeeded in "boxing in" both
the Hopkins men for some little
time and, though the time was poor,
Binford and Uhler were thus not
able to do their best work and had
to be satisfied with second and third
places. In the two-mile run, Rosen
took the lead for Hopkins for the
first three laps, then Lafayette slid
into first place and the pace proved
too much for Rosen. He finished
second.
Summary of events:
Poo-Yard Dash —Wright, Hopkins,
first; Straus, Hopkins, second; Boyce,
Lafayette, third. Time, T3A seconds.
120-Yard Hurdles—Tappan, Hopkins,
first; Maxwell, Lafayette, second ;
Dempster, Hopkins, third. Time, 163/5
seconds.
(Continued on page 1, col. 3)

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
LEHIGH LOSES HARD-FOUGHT
BATTLE
'Varsity Lacrosse Team Puts Up Splendid Game and Advances Toward
Championship.

In a contest which proved to be
easily the most exciting and hardfought seen at Homewood in many
years, the 'Varsity lacrosse team defeated Lehigh by a score of 5 to 4.
The visitors, with an unusually
fast and heavy team, held their
ground in a most determined manner and forced Hopkins to use all
of its resources to keep them from
scoring more frequently. Lehigh's
tactics, however, proved to be less
efficient than those of the characteristically well-drilled Black and Blue
squad; and, although it had a distinct advantage in weight, the
Brown and White team was unable
to cope successfully with the rapidfire work of the Hopkins attack.
A closer game has not been seen
at Homewood in many years. Time
and again the heavy Brown and
White attack would carry the ball
straight down the field, only to have
a well-placed shot stopped at the
goal.
With both teams fighting their
hardest, the game was rough at
times. As a result of over-zealous
stickwork on the part of some players, several minor injuries were sustained by players, and at the end of
the second half there were few out
of the twenty-four that left the field
who were not stiff and sore from
repeated knocks and falls.
The work of Captain Troxell,
Leibensperger, Boyce and Stuart
was most prominent in keeping the
heavy South Bethlehemites from
taking the championship. Hopkins
excelled in the finer points of teamwork and in the long run this feature counted heavily.
After this game the progress to
the championship of the Southern
division of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association should not be difficult. However, until the game
with Swarthmore has been played,
nothing definite can be said. The

A series of five lectures on Dutch
Literature and History was delivered last week by Dr. Leonard Charles Van Noppen, Queen
Wilhelmina lecturer at Columbia
University. The lectures were given
in the Donovan Room.
"The Dutch Renaissance" was the
topic of Monday's talk, in which
Dr. Van Noppen traced the course
of literature up to, and through, the
Renaissance. He showed how indelibly the marks of Dutch national
history are stamped upon its literature.
Tuesday, he discussed "Vondel,
the Dutch Shakespeare," a dramatist and poet, whose name stands
greatest in the literature of the
Netherlands. He was born in 1587
and lived to the age of 92. He
produced many works during his
long literary career, translations of
the classics, bibical dramas, dramatic
poems. Of the latter, his. greatest
and best known poem, the "Lucifer," furnished the subject for the
lecture of Wednesday, on "Vondel's
'Lucifer,' the Origin of 'Paradise
Lost.'" Professor Noppen attempted to show the influence of the
Dutch poet upon Milton's epic, as in
the use, not only of certain like
characters, but also in similar passages of thought.
The indebtedness of Milton to
Vondel for his "Samson Agonistes"
was even greater, according to the
lecturer, who spoke Thursday regarding "Vondel's 'Samson,' the
Original of Milton's 'Samson Agonistes.'" On Friday the last of the
series was delivered on "Van Eeden,
the Dutch Tolstoi, and the Literature since 1880." Frederick Van
Eeden is one of the leaders of the
Naturalist movement in Holland,
and his novels have received very
favorable attention.
Dr. Van Noppen, though a native
of North Carolina, is of Dutch
descent. Desiring to make a mark
in the literary world, he went to
Holland to study. He was named
Queen Wilhelmina lecturer, to disseminate more widely the knowledge
of Dutch history and literature in
this country. At one time he was
on the staff of the Pittsburgh
Leader; his work at present is,
however, to lecture at the principal
universities and colleges in the
country.
In connection with the course, the
Enoch Pratt Library has placed in
one of the annex building's windows on Cathedral street a collection of books upon the subject of
Dutch literature, including some
volumes of Vondel in the original.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1915.
TINGLEY PRESIDENT OF ADAMS
Newly Founded Literary Society Elects
Officers for Ensuing Term Thirtyfive Present at Meeting.

The Adams Literary Society met
for the second time last Thursday
in Room 12, and elected officers for
the coming term.
Thomas J. Tingley,'16, editor-inchief of the 1916 "Hullabaloo" and
University debater, was elected
president. Monroe Firo, of the
1917 class, was elected vice-president. Robert Duncan and Reuben
Oppenheimer, both of the class of
1918, were elected secretary and
Arthur
treasurer, respectively.
Hooper and Allen K. Chalmers, also
of the 1918 class, were elected to
serve on the boardof curators,which
is to provide programs for the meetings. President Tingley appointed
Steinbach, Hooper, Chalmers and
Oppenheimer to serve on the Membership Committee, with Steinbach
acting as chairman.
Owing to the illness of Mr. Conn
the Constitutional Committee was
unable to make its report; but Mr.
Oppenheimer reported that the election of officers was to occur twice a
year, on the second meeting in October and the first meeting in February, the present officers, however,
to hold office until next February.
The constitution will be read in full
at the next meeting.
After the election of officers the
society adjourned until Thursday,
May 5.
About thirty-five members were
present at the meeting, and lively interest was manifested throughout
the proceedings. It is expected that
the entire organization of the society will be completed in two or
three weeks, and that the Adams
will begin next year with a large
membership.

BRICKLEY A LEADER ON
HARVARD'S BASEBALL TEAM

The Harvard baseball team finished its spring Southern trip with
an easy victory over Columbia at
South Field. The Crimson, under
the tutelage of Dr. Sexton, looks
like a formidable aggregation and
should give a good account of herself in the championship games
against Yale and Princeton.
A heavy hitting outfield, a fast,
sure fielding infield, a wealth of
Ditching- material and two good
catchers comprise the Cambridge
squad. Former Harvard teams have
been weak in team batting, but this
year they seem to be unusually
strong with the stick. Consistent
hitting backed up by snappy fielding
and elusive twirling should insure
many victories to the university on
the Charles.
A look at the Crimson outfield
recalls a certain day last November
in the Yale Bowl when a Crimson
hue spread over the New Haven
landscape. Mahan, captain of this
year's eleven; Charley Brickley,
year's leader and greatest football
player of all time: and Zacks Hardwick, all-American end, spear line
drives as easily as they capture
punts.
This trio, which caused so much
consternation on the gridiron and
whose names figure so prominently
in football stories, instil fear into
the hearts of opposing pitchers
when they aproach the plate with
their warclubs. All are natural
clouters and step into the ball with
the abandon of a Cobb, Collins or
Baker.—N. Y. Evening Sun.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1915.
Athletic Progress.

The victories of the lacrosse and
baseball teams on Saturday—both
close and hard-fought battles with
strong opponents—showed the excellent mid-season form of two of
the best spring teams that have ever
represented the University and indicated the great performances that
may be expected in the so-called
"big games" that will 'conclude the
season.
The 5-to-4 victory over the Lehigh twelve—the best game of lacrosse that has been seen at. Homewood in many a year— was without
doubt the athletic event of the year,
and those who take pride in the feat
accomplished by the 'Varsity must
thank the men who won the game.
Lehigh Put up a splendid game—it
fought bitterly to the finish—but
the speed and accuracy of Coach
Wolfe's players, supplemented by
that technique of details of play for
which Hopkins is noted, told during
the long halves of play, and Hopkins nosed out the much-desired
victory by a margin of one point.
And while the spectators at
Homewood were being thrilled by
the close battle of lacrosse, a couple

The QUALITY

Rev. Dr. John Nelson Mills, who
will lecture in McCoy Hall, May 6,
at 5 P. M., on the "Progress and
Prospects of China," has recently
returned from a tour of the world
lasting several years. In his lecture
he will present the need and opportunity of Christian service in China.
Dr. Mills has spoken at the leading
institutions of learning in the West;
from Colorado College to the University of Chicago, and to many in
the East, from Harvard University
to the University of Texas. He is
a minister of the Presbyterian
Church, making his home at present
in Washington.

"Father," asked a small boy of
an editor, "is Jupiter inhabited?"
"I don't know, my son," was the
truthful answer.
Presently he was • interrupted
again. "Father, are there any sea
serpents?"
"I don't know, my son."
The little fellow was manifestly
cast down, but presently rallied and
again approached the great source
of information.
"Father, what does the North
Pole look like?"
But, alas! again the answer, "I
don't know, my son."
At last, in desperation, he inquired, with a withering emphasis,
"Father, how did Tou get to be an
editor?"—Ex.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1915.

NOBLE'S TRIPLE BREAKS UP GAME

UNDERCLASS TEAMS ORGANIZE

LAFAYETTE WINS DUAL MEET

Sutton Scores Him in Eleventh Inning
With Sacrifice Fly and Then Treats
Crowd to Pretzels.

Freshmen and Sophomores Make Preparations for Interclass Lacrosse and
Baseball Games—Close Contests Expected.

Black and Blue Puts Up Good Fight in
Close Contest, 47-57 Tappan
Stars Again.

The 'Varsity nine required eleven
innings to get the better of the
Delaware College baseball team in
the annual game at Newark, Del.,
Saturday aftenoon. The score was
7 to 6.
Jack Defandorf, who was on the
mound for Hopkins, pitched a
splendid game with the exception of
the two innings—the third and the
ninth—in which four runs were
scored. Hoch, Delaware's pitcher,
struck out ten men, and from the
third to the ninth inning allowed no
hits, but Hopkins' heavy hitting
lead-off men found him in the ninth
and eleventh periods for enough
hits to break the even score.
Bill Noble, desperate and hungry
(for it was nearly six o'clock), told
his teammates on the bench just before he went to bat in the eleventh
inning that he was due for a long
hit. He poled out a beautiful triple
to center, and scored on Sutton's
sacrifice fly, thus winning the fourth
consecutive game for the Black and
Blue.
The battle was certainly thrilling.
Hopkins got 'a lead of three runs
over Delaware in the third inning,
but the Blue and Gray evened the
score in the fifth. Then came the
struggle to break the deadlock. Hopkins scored twice in the ninth, but
Delaware evened un in its portion
of the inning. The tenth period
lasted fifteen minutes.
Capt. Pete Porter, the first to bat
for Hopkins, sent a liner to first
base, but Geoghegan fielded it in
big-league style. Then Bill Noble
drove out his triple. Inasmuch as it
was a question of getting only one
run to win, Butts Sutton concluded
that it would do to send out a fly
long enough to allow Noble to
score. This he did. Delaware went
out in one-two-three order in its
end of the inning.
One of the results of the game
was the establishment of the fact
that Coach Eddie Hooper hasn't
heart failure. "After this game,"
he said, "no doctor can ever tell me
I have heart failure. If I had it
I would have been dead before the
ninth inning."
When the game was over the
players had just enough time to
dress to catch the 6.13 train for
Baltimore. A number wanted to
"make" the cotillon and it was decided to forego the dinner which
Delaware had prepared. Butts
Sutton, dressing earlier than the
rest, found Newark's general store
and laid in a generous supply of
oranges, fruit crackers and pretzels,
(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

The Freshman-Sophomore class
teams will probably be stronger this
season and will be more evenly
matched than they have been in several years. The lacrosse teams, especially, will be well fortified with
men from the 'Varsity squad; and
consequently the annual class game
is expected to be hotly contested.
The sophomores have Stuart,
Baker and Brooks, the three 'Varsity
close-defense men, as a nucleus for
their defense; and Boyce, Wilson
and Paul Sutton on the attack.
With these men as a basis, the
second-year men are confident of
putting a fast team on the field, and
of atoning for the defeat in football
which they sulfered last fall.
The freshmen are equally hopeful
of having a winning team. Their
attack contains Wolfe, Woodward,
Frank Sutton, Mealy and Swartz—
all on the 'Varsity squad—and several other candidates, including
Evans, Hooper, Rothschild and Miller. The freshmen defense is not
as strong as that of the sophomores.
Chalmers has been showing up well
at goal. Hoffman, Gillet, P. Nelson, Love and Cromwell will probably be the other defense men.
Allen K. Chalmers, manager of
the freshmen baseball team, reports
that the prospects for a good showing are exceedingly bright. There
are a large number of candidates
out for the team, two or three men
contesting for every position. The
list of available pitchers is especially
long. There is Hollingsworth, the
'Varsity pitcher, who will probably
hurl for the freshmen, and there are
Love, Tavjor, Rolker and Witz, all
on the 'Varsity squad.
A game with the Towson High
School nine has already been arranged for the freshmen team, and
it is planned to play several other
local prenaratory schools before the
game with the sophomores.
We consider health and the right
attitude toward health as fundamental. Health is not possible
without "good times." Health of
the. body is of little value without
health of the soul, and we encourage thoughtfulness and earnestness.
Good health; clear thinking and
right attitude are ideals toward
which we are ever striving.
It requires some grit and a sense
of honor to turn one's back squarely
on his weaknesses and keep it there.

The last three events decided the
dual meet with Lafayette, held at
Homewood last Saturday, against
the Black and Blue after a close and
exciting contest. .Hopkins was in
the lead (luring the first part of the
Meet, and the tenth event found the
score tied. Then the visitors took
the lead by winning both places in
the half mile, and later ended the
contest on the best side of 57 to 47.
Tappan once more starred for
Hopkins,. being the highest individual point-winner of the meet
with seventeen and one-half points.
He won the high hurdles and the
pole vault, took second place in the
low hurdles and the broad jump.
and tied with Captain Connolly of
the Hopkins team for second place
in the high jump. His performance
in the high hurdles was exceptionally good. Straus also distinguished
himself. by his good work in the
sprints. He won the 220-yard dash
in very good time (22V-, seconds)
and was second in the Too-yard
dash. Wright, who on account of
an injured muscle had not appeared
for Hopkins before this meet, won
the Too-yard dash in beautiful
form, but in the 220 his leg went
back on him again and he was forced
to make a weak fiMsh, only taking
third place.
Kleinstehn, of Lafayette, ran a
beautiful race in the mile run and
finished in 4 minutes, 4434 seconds.
Tiall trailed him closely all the way,
but was unable to make up the
three-yard lead on the home stretch.
Maxfield, Lafayette's weight man,
made exceptionally good throws in
both the discus and shot put, making 114 feet and 43 feet. respectively, in these events. Connolly was a
good second to both performances.
The Red and White runners ran
a "heady" race in the quarter mile,
and succeeded in "boxing in" both
the Hopkins men for some little
time and, though the time was poor,
Binford and Uhler were thus not
able to do their best work and had
to be satisfied with second and third
places. In the two-mile run, Rosen
took the lead for Hopkins for the
first three laps, then Lafayette slid
into first place and the pace proved
too much for Rosen. He finished
second.
Summary of events:
Poo-Yard Dash —Wright, Hopkins,
first; Straus, Hopkins, second; Boyce,
Lafayette, third. Time, T3A seconds.
120-Yard Hurdles—Tappan, Hopkins,
first; Maxwell, Lafayette, second ;
Dempster, Hopkins, third. Time, 163/5
seconds.

LEHIGH LOSES HARD-FOUGHT
BATTLE
'Varsity Lacrosse Team Puts Up Splendid Game and Advances Toward
Championship.

In a contest which proved to be
easily the most exciting and hardfought seen at Homewood in many
years, the 'Varsity lacrosse team defeated Lehigh by a score of 5 to 4.
The visitors, with an unusually
fast and heavy team, held their
ground in a most determined manner and forced Hopkins to use all
of its resources to keep them from
scoring more frequently. Lehigh's
tactics, however, proved to be less
efficient than those of the characteristically well-drilled Black and Blue
squad; and, although it had a distinct advantage in weight, the
Brown and White team was unable
to cope successfully with the rapidfire work of the Hopkins attack.
A closer game has not been seen
at Homewood in many years. Time
and again the heavy Brown and
White attack would carry the ball
straight down the field, only to have
a well-placed shot stopped at the
goal.
With both teams fighting their
hardest, the game was rough at
times. As a result of over-zealous
stickwork on the part of some players, several minor injuries were sustained by players, and at the end of
the second half there were few out
of the twenty-four that left the field
who were not stiff and sore from
repeated knocks and falls.
The work of Captain Troxell,
Leibensperger, Boyce and Stuart
was most prominent in keeping the
heavy South Bethlehemites from
taking the championship. Hopkins
excelled in the finer points of teamwork and in the long run this feature counted heavily.
After this game the progress to
the championship of the Southern
division of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association should not be difficult. However, until the game
with Swarthmore has been played,
nothing definite can be said. The

A series of five lectures on Dutch
Literature and History was delivered last week by Dr. Leonard Charles Van Noppen, Queen
Wilhelmina lecturer at Columbia
University. The lectures were given
in the Donovan Room.
"The Dutch Renaissance" was the
topic of Monday's talk, in which
Dr. Van Noppen traced the course
of literature up to, and through, the
Renaissance. He showed how indelibly the marks of Dutch national
history are stamped upon its literature.
Tuesday, he discussed "Vondel,
the Dutch Shakespeare," a dramatist and poet, whose name stands
greatest in the literature of the
Netherlands. He was born in 1587
and lived to the age of 92. He
produced many works during his
long literary career, translations of
the classics, bibical dramas, dramatic
poems. Of the latter, his. greatest
and best known poem, the "Lucifer," furnished the subject for the
lecture of Wednesday, on "Vondel's
'Lucifer,' the Origin of 'Paradise
Lost.'" Professor Noppen attempted to show the influence of the
Dutch poet upon Milton's epic, as in
the use, not only of certain like
characters, but also in similar passages of thought.
The indebtedness of Milton to
Vondel for his "Samson Agonistes"
was even greater, according to the
lecturer, who spoke Thursday regarding "Vondel's 'Samson,' the
Original of Milton's 'Samson Agonistes.'" On Friday the last of the
series was delivered on "Van Eeden,
the Dutch Tolstoi, and the Literature since 1880." Frederick Van
Eeden is one of the leaders of the
Naturalist movement in Holland,
and his novels have received very
favorable attention.
Dr. Van Noppen, though a native
of North Carolina, is of Dutch
descent. Desiring to make a mark
in the literary world, he went to
Holland to study. He was named
Queen Wilhelmina lecturer, to disseminate more widely the knowledge
of Dutch history and literature in
this country. At one time he was
on the staff of the Pittsburgh
Leader; his work at present is,
however, to lecture at the principal
universities and colleges in the
country.
In connection with the course, the
Enoch Pratt Library has placed in
one of the annex building's windows on Cathedral street a collection of books upon the subject of
Dutch literature, including some
volumes of Vondel in the original.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1915.
TINGLEY PRESIDENT OF ADAMS
Newly Founded Literary Society Elects
Officers for Ensuing Term Thirtyfive Present at Meeting.

The Adams Literary Society met
for the second time last Thursday
in Room 12, and elected officers for
the coming term.
Thomas J. Tingley,'16, editor-inchief of the 1916 "Hullabaloo" and
University debater, was elected
president. Monroe Firo, of the
1917 class, was elected vice-president. Robert Duncan and Reuben
Oppenheimer, both of the class of
1918, were elected secretary and
Arthur
treasurer, respectively.
Hooper and Allen K. Chalmers, also
of the 1918 class, were elected to
serve on the boardof curators,which
is to provide programs for the meetings. President Tingley appointed
Steinbach, Hooper, Chalmers and
Oppenheimer to serve on the Membership Committee, with Steinbach
acting as chairman.
Owing to the illness of Mr. Conn
the Constitutional Committee was
unable to make its report; but Mr.
Oppenheimer reported that the election of officers was to occur twice a
year, on the second meeting in October and the first meeting in February, the present officers, however,
to hold office until next February.
The constitution will be read in full
at the next meeting.
After the election of officers the
society adjourned until Thursday,
May 5.
About thirty-five members were
present at the meeting, and lively interest was manifested throughout
the proceedings. It is expected that
the entire organization of the society will be completed in two or
three weeks, and that the Adams
will begin next year with a large
membership.

BRICKLEY A LEADER ON
HARVARD'S BASEBALL TEAM

The Harvard baseball team finished its spring Southern trip with
an easy victory over Columbia at
South Field. The Crimson, under
the tutelage of Dr. Sexton, looks
like a formidable aggregation and
should give a good account of herself in the championship games
against Yale and Princeton.
A heavy hitting outfield, a fast,
sure fielding infield, a wealth of
Ditching- material and two good
catchers comprise the Cambridge
squad. Former Harvard teams have
been weak in team batting, but this
year they seem to be unusually
strong with the stick. Consistent
hitting backed up by snappy fielding
and elusive twirling should insure
many victories to the university on
the Charles.
A look at the Crimson outfield
recalls a certain day last November
in the Yale Bowl when a Crimson
hue spread over the New Haven
landscape. Mahan, captain of this
year's eleven; Charley Brickley,
year's leader and greatest football
player of all time: and Zacks Hardwick, all-American end, spear line
drives as easily as they capture
punts.
This trio, which caused so much
consternation on the gridiron and
whose names figure so prominently
in football stories, instil fear into
the hearts of opposing pitchers
when they aproach the plate with
their warclubs. All are natural
clouters and step into the ball with
the abandon of a Cobb, Collins or
Baker.—N. Y. Evening Sun.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1915.
Athletic Progress.

The victories of the lacrosse and
baseball teams on Saturday—both
close and hard-fought battles with
strong opponents—showed the excellent mid-season form of two of
the best spring teams that have ever
represented the University and indicated the great performances that
may be expected in the so-called
"big games" that will 'conclude the
season.
The 5-to-4 victory over the Lehigh twelve—the best game of lacrosse that has been seen at. Homewood in many a year— was without
doubt the athletic event of the year,
and those who take pride in the feat
accomplished by the 'Varsity must
thank the men who won the game.
Lehigh Put up a splendid game—it
fought bitterly to the finish—but
the speed and accuracy of Coach
Wolfe's players, supplemented by
that technique of details of play for
which Hopkins is noted, told during
the long halves of play, and Hopkins nosed out the much-desired
victory by a margin of one point.
And while the spectators at
Homewood were being thrilled by
the close battle of lacrosse, a couple

The QUALITY
SHOP

Rev. Dr. John Nelson Mills, who
will lecture in McCoy Hall, May 6,
at 5 P. M., on the "Progress and
Prospects of China," has recently
returned from a tour of the world
lasting several years. In his lecture
he will present the need and opportunity of Christian service in China.
Dr. Mills has spoken at the leading
institutions of learning in the West;
from Colorado College to the University of Chicago, and to many in
the East, from Harvard University
to the University of Texas. He is

"Father," asked a small boy of
an editor, "is Jupiter inhabited?"
"I don't know, my son," was the
truthful answer.
Presently he was • interrupted
again. "Father, are there any sea
serpents?"
"I don't know, my son."
The little fellow was manifestly
cast down, but presently rallied and
again approached the great source
of information.
"Father, what does the North
Pole look like?"
But, alas! again the answer, "I
don't know, my son."
At last, in desperation, he inquired, with a withering emphasis,
"Father, how did Tou get to be an
editor?"—Ex.
